title: What is the future of green sustainable? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer, not yet. Consider this, if you base more than ten or fifteen percent of your power grid on wind, you are guaranteed to have brown-outs. Wind is not a constant. I lecture on the past, present, and future of renewable energy. While perovskite-based solar panels are showing a glimmer of promise, the big game-changer will be fusion. If we can crack that nut, then who needs wind? Solar always will be with us. It is vital as a form distributed power generation, especially off-grid. Ever seen one of these?  That’s a solar powered refrigerator. It allows for the proper storage of heat sensitive drugs like insulin. It can go anywhere and save lives wherever it goes. Most of the so-called green initiatives are highly inefficient and thoroughly overpriced. For instance, most household recycling is a sham. Many folks dutifully wash out their used containers before placing them in the bin. Typically they use hot water. The waste of water and heating energy totally outweighs the value of recycling. Here’s another dilemma: Disposable diapers. They are hellishly convenient and hellishly expensive. Using cloth diapers means using a lot of hot water. Where’s the downside? Babies have very thin skin and placing them in contact with the plastic of a disposable diaper—especially in a moist environment—is very questionable. But wait! There’s more: It is estimated that anywhere up to TEN PERCENT of our landfills consists of disposable diapers. Just wait until all those feces leach down into our water tables. I know that the example of disposable diapers wasn’t on topic. It was my intention to illustrate how there is no silver bullet, especially when it comes to sustainable green technologies. There is an apocryphal tale that Germany’s green programs require a quarter-million dollars per job created and displaces another five or ten workers. I’ve been to Germany twice and you would not believe the size of their wind turbines.  That’s just one blade (not the tower). When at speed, the blade tips approach transonic velocities, this results in a subsonic rumbling that is beginning to be recognized as noise pollution. Additionally, during winter, when the blades ice up, they can fling a multi-kilo chunk of ice for around a quarter mile. Then there’s the birds.  Not for nothing are these monsters called the, “Cuisinart of the Skies”. My whole point is that this early stage, sustainable green technology is a matter of trade offs. Far too many in the green movement are intractable and that makes these compromises nearly impossible. Additionally, lawmakers just can’t keep their noses out of things, despite how you can’t legislate physics. Finally, here is a Sankey diagram showing the sources and destinations of America’s generated energy. Please examine the upper left corner closely, you will see that solar, hydro, wind, and geothermal, put together, don’t even match the input of nuclear power—which provides a tiny fraction of overall global energy. Now let your eyes drift over to the right-hand side. Notice how the rejected energy exceeds that of energy services (58.1 vs 37.0 respectively)? If that doesn’t scare the living crap out of someone who’s concerned about green sustainable, I don’t know what will. At present green technology remains in its infancy. I hope this helped.

Hopefully, after watching The Planet of the Humans, short. Instead of spending $1.5 trillion a year on all these anti-carbon things that don’t actually work, but make a lot of people a great deal of money, we should instead spend only $ billions on research. Nobody with any sense buys the first iteration of a new technology; it’s big and clunky and very expensive. You wait a few years and buy it when it becomes smaller, much more useful, and cheap. In a decade of serious research, we could have saved, say $14 trillion, and now buy proper, working technologies. Currently, we’re buying solar panels and wind turbines that produce minimal electricity, only when the wind blows and in the daytime. I’d rather spend the money on Thorium liquid salt nuclear power, and battery storage. And other technologies not yet thought of. End all subsidies to wind and solar, except for research grants. Ten years delay will save us a fortune, and won’t cause any damage to the planet.

Assuming you mean energy, neither wind or solar will EVER compete with the concentrated and portable energy of oil. We may through some breakthrough with batteries make electricity portable enough to be useful (in which case it becomes competitive) but I have been watching that research since 1972 and seen a 5% improvement from useless to slightly less useless. Obviously stationary uses like a factory floor or a kitchen oven can and do make great use of electricity but when you must move it all breaks down. We will be better served using nuclear fission for electricity generation of base load with natural gas for peak and working hard to move on to fusion. Mobility will still require gas or diesel until that magic occurs in batteries.

Without question, green and sustainable products and routines will become the norm. Nothing else is possible if we are to maintain our standard of acceptable human comfort while living long and relatively healthy lives.

Efficiency is the future. Not austerity. Not magical radioactive infinite power. Green may not be the best color to pick as your mascot. Clear instead of green may be more informative. The negawatt.

Green refers to the activities that provide a more efficient use of resources and minimize the harmful impact on the environment when compared to similar products. Sustainablerefers to activities that allow a specific problem to be solved without having adverse implications in the future.
